sets.name: Drought Wallbreaker
sets.description: Thanks to its superb coverage and high Special Attack stat, Mega Charizard Y is a terrifying wallbreaker. Drought + Solar Beam allows Mega Charizard Y to subdue Water-types such Rotom-W, Gastrodon, and Tapu Fini, further restricting its defensive counterplay. Fire Blast is preferred to hit as hard as possible, though Flamethrower's perfect accuracy and greater PP make it worth consideration. Weather Ball is an interesting option, as it presents a challenge to rain teams by dealing considerable damage to Pelipper on the switch, but it comes at the cost of Mega Charizard Y losing its primary STAB move outside of sun. Scorching Sands pressures Heatran, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, while Focus Blast threatens Mega Tyranitar. Mega Charizard Y's tremendous wallbreaking prowess allows late-game sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult, Dragonite, and Volcarona to take advantage of Unaware walls that have been compromised, such as Skeledirge and Clodsire. Mega Charizard Y's sun support benefits Protosynthesis users such as Great Tusk. Mega Charizard Y appreciates entry hazard control from teammates such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Kartana, as it is extremely susceptible to Stealth Rock. It also struggles to break bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Mega Latias as well as special walls like Clodsire and Hippowdon. Weavile, Tyranitar, and Kingambit subsequently form strong offensive cores with Mega Charizard Y, as they are able to Pursuit trap its aforementioned checks, with the former being able to deal with Hippowdon as well. Mega Charizard Y's middling Speed tier and unremarkable physical bulk leave it prone to being revenge killed by faster threats such as Dragapult, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Koko. Therefore, bulky switch-ins such as Assault Vest Tangrowth, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Charizard X is a powerful setup sweeper and wallbreaker thanks to the sheer power of its Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz. Earthquake covers a vast majority of Fire-resistant Pokemon, including Heatran, Toxapex, Garganacl, and Skeledirge, as well as Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit without the recoil. Aside from granting Mega Charizard X more setup opportunities, Roost compensates for Flare Blitz recoil and its Stealth Rock weakness, allowing it to take advantage of its typing and natural bulk to soft check common foes like Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Choice Scarf Kartana as well as preventing revenge killing attempts from Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Dragon Claw is an alternative on hyper offense teams where the longevity isn't as necessary, which allows Mega Charizard X to hit Dragonite, Mega Latias, and Garchomp as well as providing neutral coverage against foes like Rotom-W, Tera Water Skeledirge, and Tera Grass Heatran. Offensive partners like Kartana, Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit can pressure the opposition early-game for Mega Charizard X to sweep more easily, as they can cripple and either pressure or overwhelm shared checks in Toxapex, Slowbro, Skeledirge, and Iron Defense Garganacl; in return, it threatens Tangrowth for Kartana, handles Gholdengo for Iron Valiant, and melts other Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Corviknight for them. Pivots like Dragapult, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T bring Mega Charizard X in safely via U-turn on Pokemon like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, respectively; the latter two in particular can remove entry hazards with Defog so it can enter the field unscathed, especially if it's not running Roost and hasn't Mega Evolved yet. Dual screen setters found on hyper offense teams, such as Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl, give Mega Charizard X an easier time setting up.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Slowbro's valuable defensive typing, solid physical bulk, and remarkable longevity between Slack Off + Regenerator make it a very reliable defensive pivot, capable of consistently checking dangerous physical attackers like Urshifu-R, Mega Medicham, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Swampert. The combination of Teleport + Future Sight lets Slowbro support its offensive teammates by providing them free entry while forcing immense pressure on a prospective switch-in. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Slowbro to switch freely in spite of any entry hazards. Tera Steel can be used in a pinch to check foes like Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Tapu Lele, letting it either cripple them with a Scald burn or use Teleport into a revenge killer. Wallbreakers such as Kingambit, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta appreciate Slowbro's FuturePort to bring them in safely on foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl and subsequently pressure their switch-ins like Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Toxapex with the impending Future Sight. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Heatran help cover threats like Tapu Koko, Volcarona, and Gholdengo, respectively; in return, Slowbro deals with Ground- and Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Urshifu-R. Corviknight, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole cover other physical attackers such as Kartana, Kingambit, and Weavile that Slowbro struggles with; the former two remove entry hazards with Defog in case Slowbro is forced to take a Knock Off, while the latter can make use of Future Sight to wallbreak easier.

sets.name: Pink Blob (Defensive)
sets.description: Thanks to its gargantuan Eviolite-boosted special bulk alongside a lack of relevant weaknesses, Chansey stands firmly as a formidable wall that blanket checks the metagame's special attackers, including Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona. Toxic lets Chansey whittle them down, especially in conjunction with repeated Seismic Tosses, while Thunder Wave punishes poison-immune foes like Heatran and Toxapex and cripples switch-ins such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Chansey can provide cleric support with Aromatherapy, especially since it can switch into status users like Clodsire and Rotom-W thanks to Natural Cure. However, Stealth Rock can be used if the team lacks another user, and Chansey can do it sufficiently by outlasting common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T. Tera Steel allows it to reliably check Tapu Lele, Hatterene, and Tornadus-T, and it prevents Chansey from being poisoned. Chansey is generally reserved for bulkier builds that appreciate its defensive profile and can tolerate its overall passivity. Sturdy walls like Skeledirge, Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Corviknight can cover physical attackers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Kartana for Chansey. Skeledirge's Unaware helps against setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Mega Charizard X that attempt to use Chansey as setup fodder, while Corviknight's Defog alleviates Chansey from entry hazard pressure that would overwhelm it easily. Knock Off and Trick absorbers like Clefable, Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo make sure that Chansey can keep its valuable Eviolite; Additionally, Mega Scizor helps deal with Psyshock Tapu Lele, Gholdengo threatens Calm Mind Hatterene, and Calm Mind Clefable overwhelms Heatran—especially if it's paralyzed—all of which are special attackers that can beat Chansey one-on-one.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Gyarados is a powerful sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to Dragon Dance, Mold Breaker, and its high Attack stat. Mega Gyarados also possesses a valuable defensive typing that helps against foes such as Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Kingambit. Mold Breaker lets Mega Gyarados break through foes such as Tera Fairy Gastrodon and Skeledirge, the latter being a troublesome foe for teammates such as Dragonite and Dragapult. Substitute allows Mega Gyarados to avoid status from foes such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W while also avoiding revenge killers such as Tapu Lele and Kartana. Alternatively, Earthquake lets Mega Gyarados break through Toxapex and Rotom-W. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery, Haze, and Iron Defense from Toxapex and Skarmory, though it is generally not preferred since it leaves Mega Gyarados vulnerable to Scald burns and revenge killers such as Tapu Lele. Mega Gyarados appreciates dual screen support from Tapu Koko, which allows it to set up more easily. In return, Mega Gyarados can pivot into Ground-type attacks from foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Gyarados struggles against physical walls such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Buzzwole, so it appreciates teammates such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant handling them. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Landorus-T and Glimmora helps weaken defensive foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Water Landorus-T for Mega Gyarados. Teammates such as Dragonite also appreciate Mega Gyarados weakening defensive foes such as Skeledirge and Ferrothorn so it can clean late-game.

sets.name: Extreme Killer (Dragon Dance)
sets.description: Dragonite's high Attack stat, Dragon Dance, and Tera Normal make it a good user of Extreme Speed, being able to effectively clean late-game. Earthquake helps Dragonite eliminate Normal-resistant Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Heatran. Roost improves Dragonite's longevity and enables it to acquire multiple boosts against passive opponents. Roost lets Dragonite check Volcarona and rain sweepers such as Barraskewda throughout the entire match. Ice Spinner is another choice that clears the priority-blocking Psychic Terrain and hits Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Dragapult super effectively. Fire Punch can be used to hit bulky Steel-types not weak to Ground such as Corviknight, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn. An Adamant nature is usually preferred to maximize Extreme Speed's damage output, but a Jolly nature enables Dragonite to outspeed Tapu Koko and the Normal-immune Dragapult after a single Dragon Dance. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures that Dragonite will always retain Multiscale even if entry hazards are up, but if the team's entry hazard control is good, Silk Scarf is another option that boosts Extreme Speed's power. Dragonite fits well on offensive teams as a priority-using revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Entry hazard support from Great Tusk and Garchomp can help chip down bulky targets such as opposing Great Tusk into range of its attacks. Tapu Lele poses a serious threat to Dragonite, as not only does its Psychic Terrain block Extreme Speed on grounded targets, but with a Choice Scarf it can also outspeed and deal massive damage to Dragonite even after setup, especially if Dragonite has not Terastallized yet. Gholdengo is a good partner, as it can switch in on and threaten Tapu Lele and prevent the opponent from removing entry hazards. Dragonite often struggles against Unaware users such as Dondozo and Skeledirge, so Pokemon that can grab momentum against them are appreciated teammates. Rotom-W and Tapu Koko can come relatively freely on Dondozo and threaten it with a Volt Switch while Heatran and Mega Diancie can switch into and set up Stealth Rock against Skeledirge. Strong wallbreakers like Mega Medicham, Mega Charizard Y, and Zamazenta all take advantage of Pokemon that Dragonite tends to struggle with, such as Dondozo, allowing it to sweep more easily late-game.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Thanks to its solid special bulk and excellent longevity between Slack Off and Regenerator, Slowking establishes itself as a passable pivot in the metagame. It can switch into foes like Tornadus-T and non-Toxic Heatran, and it can even scout for Choice Specs users such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele. Future Sight + Teleport or Chilly Reception lets Slowking support its frail offensive teammates such as Mega Lopunny and Dragapult, giving them safe switch ins and amplifying their wallbreaking prowess afterwards. Teleport is a much more reliable way of pivoting, as its higher PP makes it more valuable in longer games and it provides Slowking's teammates with a safe switch in against Ferrothorn and other Teleport users like Blissey and Slowbro. Alternatively, Chilly Reception's snow helps disrupt weather teams like sun and rain as well as support Ice-type teammates like Kyurem and Weavile with its Defense boost. Tera Fairy improves Slowking's matchup against Dragapult and Tapu Koko and maintains its Fighting resistance against Mega Lopunny, while Tera Dark lets it better stomach Ghost-type attacks from Gholdengo and Dragapult at the cost of being weaker against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Both Tera choices importantly prevent Slowking from being Pursuit trapped by Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. Wallbreakers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Kingambit appreciate Slowking's slow pivoting, with the looming Future Sight pressuring their switch-ins like Toxapex, Buzzwole, and defensive Great Tusk. Moreover, Slowking switches into their revenge killers, notably Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Tangrowth cover foes like Weavile, Tapu Koko, and Kartana, respectively; Ferrothorn and Tangrowth also deal with rain wallbreakers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda that would otherwise overwhelm Slowking despite its Water resistance, with the latter in particular forming a Regnerator core with Slowking.

sets.name: Bulky Swords Dance
sets.description: Mega Scizor leverages its great bulk and solid defensive typing to serve as a sturdy check to many Pokemon—including Weavile, Kartana, and Tapu Lele—and a solid wincon as well. U-turn allows it to serve as a pivot: easily switching it out of checks such as Gholdengo, Urshifu-R, and Mega Charizard Y, it brings in teammates like Tapu Koko and Dragapult to deal with them. Close Combat can be used to dispose of Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran much more quickly, greatly denting them on the switch. The given EV spread allows Mega Scizor to survive two Close Combats from Mega Lopunny after Stealth Rock and outspeed uninvested Heatran, with the HP and Special Defense EVs helping it check Tapu Lele. Mega Scizor's pivot support is extremely valuable to Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Zamazenta, which all also appreciate how well it exploits defensive Pokemon such as Clodsire, Ferrothorn, and Landorus-T. Rotom-W forms a strong VoltTurn core with Mega Scizor as well, with both pivoting out on their checks and racking up solid chip damage over time. Nasty Plot Tornadus-T appreciates Mega Scizor pressuring specially defensive walls and offensive Pokemon like Weavile and Clodsire, letting it go all-in as an offensive wallbreaker with ease. Mega Scizor wearing down Rotom-W and Heatran is also particularly useful for Tornadus-T, as these Pokemon can heavily damage or cripple Tornadus-T in one way or another. Mega Scizor being completely countered by Gholdengo mandates a Pursuit trapper like Weavile or Kingambit to pressure it. Skeledirge also hard counters Mega Scizor, encouraging the aforementioned teammates as well as Garganacl and Heatran.

sets.name: Swords Dance + 3 Attacks
sets.description: This set takes on a much more offensive role, using its solid defensive typing for easy entry points against Pokemon like Weavile and Kingambit, setting up, and threatening the vast majority of the metagame with its strong Technician-boosted attacks. Close Combat KOes Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn, as well as providing a strong neutral hit against Rotom-W. Dual Wingbeat hits Clodsire and Toxapex for reliable neutral damage, hits Zamazenta super effectively, and breaks Substitute against Shed Tail hyper offense teams and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Knock Off is an alternative to hit Gholdengo reliably and remove items like Leftovers from Rotom-W and Heavy-Duty Boots from Tornadus-T, Skeledirge, and Volcarona. This allows a teammate or Mega Scizor to wear them down much more easily. Knock Off is especially relevant in Rotom-W's case, as removing Leftovers makes it easier to put into KO range of +2 Close Combat. Running Knock Off makes Toxapex a much worse matchup, however, so Pokemon like Great Tusk and Tapu Koko that can pressure it are appreciated. Sand Tomb can be used to reliably beat Clodsire, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, preventing them from reliably checking it. Offensive Mega Scizor fits much better on hyper offense teams, which appreciate its incredibly valuable—though short-term—defensive utility. Grimmsnarl is a perfect teammate, providing dual screens to let it set up against foes like Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Landorus-T; it also pivots Mega Scizor in and appreciates it baiting in Gholdengo, which prevents Grimmsnarl from pivoting as effectively. Gholdengo itself is also a notable partner, as it appreciates Mega Scizor dispatching the most popular Dark-types in Weavile and Kingambit. Entry hazards from suicide leads like Landorus-T and Garchomp allow Mega Scizor to clean late-game, as its foes must be chipped before any sweeping is done. Entry hazards particularly help in wearing down checks like Urshifu-R and bulkier Garchomp sets. Mega Scizor struggles against bulky Steel-resistant Pokemon like Rotom-W and Volcarona; Dragonite and Dragapult can take care of the latter, switching into Volcarona to set up as it switches into Mega Scizor, whereas Great Tusk can remove Leftovers from the former, making it easier for Mega Scizor to dispatch with +2 Close Combat. Physically defensive Unaware walls in Skeledirge and Dondozo completely wall Mega Scizor, so offensive Pokemon that can bait in or wear down these foes, including Iron Valiant, make for solid partners.

sets.name: Pink Blob
sets.description: Blissey's immense special bulk, useful utility moves, and reliable recovery allow it to function as a niche specially defensive pivot, as it checks threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Mega Charizard Y. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to pressure anything that isn't a Ghost-type with meaningful damage. Toxic is the preferred option to cripple Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona. Thunder Wave can also be used to annoy fast threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. It also allows Blissey to status Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Kartana. Teleport allows Blissey to safely pivot in teammates like Dragapult, Zamazenta, and Mega Medicham. However, Blissey is an acceptable Stealth Rock user if no other fits on your team. Shadow Ball can be considered as a niche option to break Dragapult's Substitutes and chip offensive Gholdengo, but it usually isn't worth dropping other moves. Tera Fairy gives Blissey a Fighting resistance in exchange for negligible Poison and Steel weaknesses, and it reduces the damage it takes from Pursuit users like Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. This should be used if Blissey absolutely has to take on a Fighting- or Dark-type like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, or Weavile. Blissey's defensive profile makes it a liability into certain Ghost-types, specifically Dragon Dance Dragapult and Gholdengo. Kingambit is a great option that deals with the former two threats while also benefitting from Blissey bringing it in safely with Teleport. Other wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Medicham also appreciate pivot support and benefit from Blissey spreading Thunder Wave. A switch-in to powerful physical attackers, like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, and Kingambit, is necessary. Options like Toxapex, Slowbro, Skarmory, and Great Tusk can help out on this front. Knock Off is irritating for Blissey, as losing its Heavy-Duty Boots is quite detrimental to its pivoting efforts. Options such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor can help out in this regard.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Mega Tyranitar serves as a valuable Stealth Rock setter and Pursuit trapper due to its powerful STAB moves, great bulk, and Rock / Dark typing, allowing it to handle Ghost- and Flying-types well. Stone Edge threatens common Defoggers in Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Rotom-W to ensure its Stealth Rock stays on the field. Crunch dents Pokemon like Dragapult and Gholdengo while doing sizable damage to Gastrodon and Ferrothorn. Alternatively, Superpower can be used over Crunch to immediately threaten Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn, but it leaves Mega Tyranitar unable to pressure Pokemon like Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Reuniclus. Pursuit traps Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. 108 Speed EVs allow Mega Tyranitar to outspeed Gholdengo. Mega Tyranitar's middling defensive typing leaves it extremely vulnerable to Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta. As such, defensive Pokemon like Zapdos, Gholdengo, and Toxapex pair well with Mega Tyranitar, as they cover the threats it would struggle with. Toxapex in particular appreciates Mega Tyranitar trapping Heatran and Gholdengo with Pursuit, after which it can then stack Toxic Spikes. This, along with Mega Tyranitar's Stealth Rock, wears down each other's checks like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Zamazenta. Mega Tyranitar also appreciates Pokemon that can deal with Ground-types, such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Tangrowth. Fighting-type partners such as Iron Valiant and Zamazenta greatly appreciate Mega Tyranitar removing Pokemon like Gholdengo and Reuniclus. Mega Tyranitar's sand enables Excadrill, which is a great offensive partner for it. Excadrill is able to snipe Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Kingambit, while Tyranitar deals with Flying-types like Zapdos and Mega Charizard Y in return. Mega Tyranitar can also chip Pokemon like Rotom-W and Landorus-T, which enables Excadrill break past them more easily.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description: Pelipper is a staple pick on rain teams thanks to its ability, Drizzle. Its physical bulk combined with Scald lets it check and potentially cripple foes such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Scizor, and Great Tusk. Hurricane is an alternative to Defog on teams that use Tornadus-T for entry hazard control, which offers better neutral coverage and the ability to hit foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran. Pelipper also operates as a slow pivot with U-turn, which is greatly appreciated by the team's wallbreakers to ensure that they can enter the field safely. Tera Ground offers an Electric immunity for threats such as Tapu Koko, whereas Tera Steel offers a strong defensive typing, letting Pelipper check Pokemon like Extreme Speed Dragonite in a pinch. As the premier rain setter, Pokemon that rely on rain to boost their power or operate effectively within it, such as Mega Swampert, Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Urshifu-R, make for common teammates. Mega Swampert offers a valuable Electric immunity for Pelipper, checking foes such as Tapu Koko. Tornadus-T can provide entry hazard control with Defog, letting Pelipper enter the field and summon rain without having to fear taking hazard damage. Ferrothorn takes advantage of Pelipper's typing and ability to form a solid defensive core and provide a robust blanket check for opposing rain. In return, Pelipper alleviates Ferrothorn's massive Fire weakness by setting rain, and it can check threats that Ferrothorn fails to cover, such as Mega Lopunny.

sets.name: Defensive Magic Bounce
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Mega Medicham is a tremendously strong wallbreaker due to Pure Power, strong STAB moves, and coverage. Fake Out lets Mega Medicham chip down and revenge kill Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. It also can let Mega Medicham stall out rain, Toxic, and Terrain on foes, all while putting opponents into range for one of its stronger attacks safely. Ice Punch lets Mega Medicham get rid of Landorus-T and Dragonite, which can enable it to freely use its STAB moves. Bullet Punch can be used to snipe Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Weavile, and it also removes revenge killers like Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny after chip damage. Thunder Punch can be used to hit Slowbro, and in tandem with Electric Terrain, it can 2HKO Pokemon like Gholdengo and Victini. Alternatively, Thief can be used to immediately damage the aforementioned Pokemon, so it can use its STAB moves more. Due to Mega Medicham’s frailty and mediocre Speed tier, it is easily revenge killed. Defensive partners like Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn help check threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Knock Off and Pursuit users like Kingambit and Weavile also support Mega Medicham, as they break through Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon Mega Medicham struggle with, such as Slowbro, Victini, Gholdengo and Skeledirge, allowing it to consistently use its STAB attacks. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn benefit Mega Medicham, as it forces a lot of switches and entry hazards wear down checks quickly. Tapu Koko is a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it handles Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Slowbro reliably and powers up Mega Medicham's Thunder Punch. Tapu Lele can also be a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it powers up Zen Headbutt to insane levels, but blocking Fake Out and Bullet Punch from being used can be problematic. Pokemon like Volcarona and Kartana appreciate Torandus-T, Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Gholdengo being pressured constantly by Mega Medicham, enabling them to wreak havoc once the checks are removed or chipped.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Floatzel is an incredible wallbreaker on rain teams, making use of its decent Attack stat powered by its Choice Band. Low Kick hits Ferrothorn and Ice Spinner hits Dragapult and Dragonite more reliably. However, because of Tera Water, its Water-type moves are all boosted considerably, so coverage is often unnecessary. Aqua Jet gives Floatzel priority outside of rain against weakened targets such as Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, and it bypasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tornadus-T and Zapdos all appreciate Floatzel's offensive capabilities, as it deals with wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Mega Diancie, Gholdengo, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Valiant. Zapdos can reliably check Water-types that counter Floatzel like Slowbro and Dodonzo. Tornadus-T can weaken and cripple Floatzel checks in Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Ferrothorn, as Knock Off removes Leftovers from them, making it easier for Floatzel to wallbreak. Offensive partners like Manaphy and Mega Swampert can overwhelm those same Water-resistant Pokemon as well as Dragonite. Ferrothorn can check priority users such as the aforementioned Dragonite and Kingambit, alleviating Floatzel's weakness to them.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Gastrodon finds itself a valuable role in National Dex primarily off its invaluable Water and Electric immunities, allowing it to handle terrifying rain sweepers such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert and answer Rotom-W perfectly. Scald lets Gastrodon threaten a burn against otherwise safe switch-ins such as Ferrothorn and Dragonite. Toxic better threatens defensive Pokemon such as opposing Gastrodon, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. Earthquake threatens Pokemon like Heatran, Clodsire, and Gholdengo. Relaxed should be selected as Gastrodon's nature if using Earthquake to not lower its damage output; Bold should be used otherwise. Tera Fairy can be used in a pinch to grant Gastrodon a resistance to Fighting against Urshifu-R and Barraskweda and a Dark resistance against Kingambit. The given EV spread maximizes Gastrodon's physical bulk to better take on the likes of Floatzel, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R. Gastrodon fits best on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its defensive qualities while being able to supplement its passivity with offensive wallbreakers. Pokemon such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo can switch into Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Kartana and Ferrothorn; In return, Gastrodon provides entry hazard support to wear down answers such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Clodsire. Strong, fast wallbreakers like Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta love having Gastrodon as a fallback measure against the myriad of Water-type revenge killers on rain such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert. If Gastrodon opts to use Spikes, it likes having Stealth Rock setters such as Heatran and Mega Diancie as partners to form an effective entry hazard-stacking core.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Garchomp serves as an excellent wallbreaker that possesses great defensive utility, having an Electric-type immunity and being a check to Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Outrage with Dragonium Z muscles through Pokemon like Great Tusk, Tangrowth, and Ting-Lu. Garchomp fits best on offensive teams; Pokemon like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Tapu Koko benefit from it breaking through Pokemon like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Dragonite. Tapu Koko makes a stellar partner because it can pivot on Garchomp targets in Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. In return, Tapu Koko threatens Corviknight and Slowbro, two major roadblocks for Garchomp. Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kingambit can pressure revenge killers such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Dragapult thanks to their strong priority while taking several attacks from them. Rotom-W switches into Pokemon that threaten Garchomp such as Great Tusk and Tornadus-T. Garchomp can take care of Pokemon Rotom-W pivots out on such as Gastrodon, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: TankChomp
sets.description: Garchomp possesses great role compression and is a good check to contact attackers like Mega Scizor, Dragonite, and Mega Lopunny. Toxic can cripple switch-ins such as Landorus-T, Tangrowth, and Rotom-W. Dragon Tail can stop any setup attempts from Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Dragonite lacking Ice Spinner and can wear down Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Flamethrower can rip through Pokemon like Kartana, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn. Tera Ghost lets Garchomp spinblock Great Tusk and switch into Fighting-type moves from Pokemon like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta, while Tera Water grants resistances to Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Ice- and Water-type moves from Weavile, Floatzel, and Urshifu-R as well as neutrality to Fairy-type attacks from Iron Valiant and Mega Diancie. Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and improves Garchomp's matchup against Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragapult. The given Speed EVs with a Jolly Nature allows Garchomp to outspeed Timid Gholdengo, while maximizing its physical bulk. Teammates like Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, and Volcarona can cover Garchomp's Ice and Fairy weaknesses and threaten out a majority of Garchomp checks such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Mega Diancie. In return, Garchomp can switch into Rock- and Fire-type Pokemon like Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Volcarona. Knock Off Kingambit and Weavile support Garchomp by crippling common Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Mega Garchomp is a passable wallbreaker thanks to its its staggering Attack stat alongside Swords Dance, busting through bulky Pokemon like Garganacl, Hippowdon, and Toxapex. Its typing and solid natural bulk grant it it multiple setup opportunities, such as in the face of Volcarona, Mega Tyranitar, non-Toxic Heatran, and Zapdos. Scale Shot's multi-hit nature makes it effective against Dragonite and Substitute users like Kyurem and Seperior, as well as offensive teams supported by Cyclizar's Shed Tail. Most importantly, the Speed boost lets Mega Garchomp outpace would-be revenge killers like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and—if it decides not to Mega Evolve yet—Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, allowing it to potentially clean up late-game. Fire Fang hits Skarmory, Corviknight, Tangrowth, and cleanly OHKOes Ferrothorn at +2. Mega Garchomp works well on offensive teams, ranging from offense to hyper offense. Pivots like Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Victini give Mega Garchomp easy entry, bringing it onto their switch-ins such as Clodsire, Toxapex, Heatran, and Skeledirge, respectively. Tapu Fini provides Misty Terrain to prevent Mega Garchomp from being crippled by the aforementioned walls—at the cost of weakening its Scale Shot, however—as well as a switch-in to Ice Shard users like Baxcalibur and Weavile that can revenge kill Mega Garchomp easily. Dual screens and Shed Tail support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl and Cyclizar give Mega Garchomp more setup opportunities. Setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Dragonite enjoy Mega Garchomp pressuring foes like Skeledirge and Toxapex. Special wallbreakers like the aforementioned Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Dragapult help against physical walls such as Dondozo and Tera Water Skeledirge that Mega Garchomp struggles with; Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain also prevents Mega Garchomp's sweep from being cut short by priority attacks from the likes of Weavile, Mega Lopunny, and Kingambit.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Hippowdon is a bulky Ground-type wall and Stealth Rock setter able to switch into threatening offensive Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Mega Charizard Y. It can find plenty of time to set up Stealth Rock and spread chip damage with Toxic and its ability Sand Stream. Sand Stream also allows Hippowdon to disrupt opposing weather, which is bolstered by its positive matchup against every other weather setter. Toxic notably nets a ton of chip damage on Defoggers attempting to get rid of Hippowdon's Stealth Rock and Ground-Immune Pokemon switching into Earthquake, such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y. Hippowdon can Terastallize into the Steel typing to avoid Toxic in addition to Grass-, Water-, and Ice-type attacks while maintaining its sand immunity and Stealth Rock resistance. Even beyond the simple type matchup chart changes, it allows Hippowdon to more easily check its targets such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Lele, Zapdos, and Mega Diancie. Maximum Special Defense EVs are ran due to Hippowdon having more valuable special targets than physical, namely the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Lopunny and Tornadus-T appreciate Hippowdon's presence, as it checks both Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zapdos while setting up Stealth Rock to help wear down their checks. Defensively, Hippowdon supports Pokemon such as Garganacl and Skarmory; Garganacl appreciates the sand and its attached benefits and Skarmory appreciates the sturdy Ground-type anchor and special wall. Hippowdon struggles to fend off strong physical attackers like Kingambit, Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados. For this reason, it pairs exquisitely with strong physical walls such as Skarmory and Buzzwole. Hippowdon also suffers from a Spikes vulnerability, meaning it appreciates Defog support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Zapdos.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Thanks to its high Speed, great Attack stat, and good STAB combination, Weavile is able to tear apart offensive teams and set itself apart from other Pursuit trappers in Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar. It can easily trap Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Choice Specs Dragapult with Pursuit. Triple Axel has good neutral coverage and threatens a KO on foes like Kartana, Mega Charizard Y, and Iron Valiant, while Knock Off removes items from the likes of Toxapex and Ferrothorn and provides good utility. Ice Shard helps revenge kill Dragapult and faster foes that have been weakened like Mega Lopunny and Tapu Koko. Tera Dark propels Weavile's Knock Off to stellar levels of damage, possibly 2HKOing defensive Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn after Stealth Rock while also removing its own weakness to Stealth Rock. Alternatively, Tera Ice allows Weavile to more easily revenge kill Dragapult, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Koko while also boosting its Triple Axel to insane levels. Although it can safely take unresisted hits from full, Weavile is really frail, so it appreciates being brought onto the field by pivots like Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Slowbro. The latter also provides Future Sight support, which allows Weavile to beat its most common checks, being Toxapex, Corviknight, and Urshifu-R. It also works well with Pokemon that like having Psychic- and Ghost-types like Gholdengo, Dragapult, and Tapu Lele being removed, like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta. Weavile also appreciates Spikes support from setters like Ting-Lu and Ferrothorn to weaken opposing Ferrothorn and Toxapex, as well as Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W to prevent it from being worn down by entry hazards.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Weavile's great Speed and Attack paired with Swords Dance makes it one of the most versatile Pokemon in the metagame, being able to wallbreak, revenge kill, and clean late-game. Most of Weavile's checks, such as Urshifu-R, Kingambit, and Heatran, aren't long-term checks and don't like losing their item. It also requires a minimal amount of chip damage on Pokemon like Buzzwole, Iron Hands, and Toxapex to effectively break them. Triple Axel is used for the larger damage output, but Ice Spinner can be used for a consistent and accurate STAB move. Icicle Crash avoids residual damage from contact abilities like Iron Barbs while also avoiding Static, Flame Body, and Rocky Helmet. Knock Off is usually preferred, as it can remove items from Toxapex and Ferrothorn and support Weavile's team, but Darkinium Z paired with Throat Chop allows Weavile to nuke its checks, mainly Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn. Tera Dark removes Weavile's weakness to Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor while also propelling Knock Off's damage to nearly unstoppable levels. Pivot support from the likes of Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Koko helps Weavile by bringing it safely onto the field while also allowing it to set up, making it more consistent. Magnezone works well with Weavile, as it can trap and remove Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight for it. In return, Weavile pressures Ground-types like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Weavile also appreciates being paired with strong wallbreakers that share checks with it such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Mega Mawile, as they can overwhelm them throughout the game. Weavile enjoys Spikes support from Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp, as it forces chip damage on its checks, such as Mega Scizor, Toxapex, and Iron Hands.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Magnezone carves itself a niche thanks to Magnet Pull, which allows it to trap and remove Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, potentially forcing the latter three to Terastallize so teammates such as Kartana and Tapu Lele can beat them. Volt Switch lets Magnezone maintain momentum while eliminating foes such as Skarmory and chipping Heatran, which cannot be trapped and removed consistently. Alternatively, Tera Blast + Tera Fighting lets Magnezone remove Kingambit, potentially forcing it to Terastallize as well. Hidden Power Fire hits foes such as the aforementioned Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Ferrothorn. Toxic is another alternative that punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon, Ting-Lu, and Hippowdon, though it can be difficult to justify over other alternatives, as it hinders Magnezone's effectiveness as a trapper. Magnezone should only Terastallize when it can trap and eliminate Kingambit, since teammates such as Dragapult and Dragonite take advantage of Tera better. The given EV spread allows Magnezone to survive an unboosted Sacred Sword from Kartana. Teammates such as Dragonite and Kartana appreciate Magnezone removing foes such as Skarmory and Ferrothorn, allowing them to sweep easier. The former can also safely switch into Ground-type attacks for Magnezone, while the latter threatens troublesome Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Teammates such as Dragapult and Landorus-T provide pivoting support for Magnezone, granting it free entry against foes such as Skarmory and Kingambit to ease prediction. Dragapult in particular appreciates Magnezone trapping and removing Kingambit, allowing it to sweep without fear of being Pursuit trapped.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Rotom-W is a stupendously effective pivot on teams because its great defensive profile allows it to check a laundry list of threats like Mega Swampert, Tornadus-T, and Mega Scizor. Volt Switch lets Rotom-W start the spin cycle, pivoting out on opposing threats that it lures in like Ferrothorn and Dragapult, helping to position teammates favorably. Hydro Pump is a fantastic complement to Volt Switch, leaving Ground-types like Great Tusk and Landorus-T out to dry. Will-O-Wisp neutralizes physical sweepers like Mega Scizor, Kingambit, and Dragonite, hampering their hopes to use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Pain Split provides Rotom-W longevity in conjunction with Leftovers, but Defog can be used for entry hazard control, as Rotom-W easily folds common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Despite this, Rotom-W struggles to remove entry hazards against offensive setters like Garchomp and often misses the recovery that Pain Split offers. Tera Ghost improves Rotom-W’s matchup against the likes of Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham while letting it spinblock against Great Tusk. Tera Steel gives Rotom-W a Toxic immunity and valuable resistances, improving its prospects against the likes of Kartana, Clodsire, and Toxapex. Strong wallberakers like Dragapult, Heatran, and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T all appreciate Rotom-W positioning them against walls like Ferrothorn, Gholdengo, and Dragonite. Iron Valiant likes Rotom-W luring out Dragon-types like Dragapult and Dragonite. Teammates such as Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor can check Grass-types for Rotom-W as well. Notably, Mega Scizor forms a great VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as Mega Scizor irons out threats that Rotom-W has trouble with like Kartana, Weavile, and Tapu Lele, while Rotom-W can deal with common Mega Scizor checks such as Zapdos and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Rotom-W functions as a shockingly potent pivot, as a lightning-quick Volt Switch allows it to reliably create big surges of momentum for teammates. Will-O-Wisp reliably chips down bulkier threats like Mega Scizor and Garchomp while also surprising faster physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny. Thunder Wave is an option that can pour a cold water onto a sea of speedy sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Kartana, slowing them down. Trick stifles walls like Ferrothorn and Gastrodon who could otherwise stem the tide of Rotom-W’s momentum. Choice Scarf Rotom-W should not be Terastalizing in most cases, but a Steel or Ghost typing can be situationally useful against prominent metagame forces such as Great Tusk and Tapu Lele. Other pivots such as Mega Scizor, Tornadus-T, and Victini can create formidable VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W. Victini in particular deals with Grass-types like Ferrothorn and Kartana, while Rotom-W can threaten physically defensive walls such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Strong wallbreakers like Heatran, Iron Valiant, and Mega Medicham pair swimmingly with Rotom-W, as they plow through common defensive staples such as Gastrodon and Ferrothorn and benefit from Rotom-W pivoting them into advantageous positions.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Hisuian Zoroark plays as a terrifying setup sweeper with its Nasty Plot set, as it has an amazing STAB combination and can bait Pokemon with Illusion. It can break through Heatran, Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit with Focus Blast, which in tandem with Tera Fighting allows Hisuian Zoroark to strengthen its Focus Blast to break the aforementioned threats more easily while also baiting Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Setup sweepers and wallbreakers like Mega Scizor and Iron Valiant appreciate Hisuian Zoroark baiting Skeledirge and Gholdengo. In return, Mega Scizor deals with Weavile and Kartana while Iron Valiant threatens Ting-Lu and Kingambit. Great Tusk is also a valuable teammate, as it deals with threats like Kingambit and Mega Lopunny while also providing general utility. While Hisuian Zoroark is powerful, it is vulernable to revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. As such, Pokemon like Zapdos, Slowbro, Ferrothorn, Kingambit and Great Tusk are good partners. Checks to revenge killers like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult are recommended; these include Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Heatran.

sets.name: Happy Hour
sets.description: With Happy Hour + Normalium Z, Hisuian Zoroark becomes a decent wincon, being given setup opportunities by baiting Pokemon with Illusion. +1 Focus Blast OHKOes Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn and Dark-types like Weavile and Mega Gyarados. Happy Hour Hisuian Zoroark is best suited on hyper offense teams because it can take advantage of dual screens to set up more easily. Hisuian Zoroark can disguise as Defiant Kingambit and bait Kingambit checks like Great Tusk and Skarmory. Tapu Koko can provide dual screens and pivot into Hisuian Zoroark against Pokemon like Gholdengo and Tornadus-T; this is best when Hisuian Zoroark is disguised as Kingambit or Mega Gyarados. Grimmsnarl is also an excellent teammate because it provides dual screens and lures and KOs Kingambit with Superpower. Tapu Lele appreciates Hisuian Zoroark beating Steel-types like Gholdengo and Heatran; Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain also blocks Kingambit's Sucker Punch, letting Hisuian Zoroark KO it. Similarly, Mega Gyarados offensively checks Kingambit and wallbreaks early-game, letting Hisuian Zoroark sweep late-game. Dragapult can form an offensive Ghost-spam core with Hisuian Zoroark and appreciates it KOing Dark-types with Focus Blast. Entry hazard support from setters like Landorus-T and Glimmora allows Hisuian Zoroark to sweep more easily, since it struggles to OHKO most Pokemon even at +1.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Amoonguss is a decent wall that serves as a stopgap against rain wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Floatzel while also checking other offensive threats like Kartana, Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R. Regenerator allows Amoonguss to check those same threats long-term; it also prevents it from being worn down by pivots like Rotom-W and Tapu Koko as well as entry hazards if its Heavy-Duty Boots is removed via Knock Off. Spore incapacitates switch-ins such as Heatran, Volcarona, and Dragapult; the latter two would otherwise use it as setup fodder, while the former completely walls Amoonguss by being immune to Sludge Bomb. Sludge Bomb spreads status against the aforementioned Volcarona and Dragapult as well as bulkier switch-ins like Skeledirge and Tornadus-T and threatens Iron Valiant. Hidden Power Fire lets Amoonguss chip Poison-immune foes like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor as well as OHKO Kartana, preventing them from safely switching in. Heavy-Duty Boots lets it switch in as much as needed without fear of entry hazard damage; it also prevents Regenerator recovery from being stifled in longer games. Rocky Helmet is an alternative that wears down contact attackers like Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T as well as the aforementioned rain wallbreakers in Barraskewda and Floatzel. It should only be used if entry hazard control is decent enough, however, with support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W. Tera Water provides invaluable resistances against Fire and Ice, letting Amoonguss potentially get an emergency Sludge Bomb or Spore in against foes like Weavile and Heatran. Tera Steel is an alternative that lets Amoonguss emergency check offensive foes like Tapu Lele while also giving it a better matchup against non-Heat Wave Tornadus-T; it also retains the Ice resistance given by Tera Water. Rotom-W is an excellent partner, as it stifles offensive and defensive Pokemon alike that Amoonguss struggles with, such as Heatran, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. In return, Amoonguss takes pressure off Rotom-W as a check to rain wallbreakers and can deal with Rotom-W switch-ins like Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. Gholdengo completely counters Amoonguss by virtue of its immunity to Spore and it taking negligible damage from Hidden Power Fire; as such, checks to it such as Kingambit and Poison Jab Clodsire are recommended, with the latter forcing Gholdengo to Terastallize so it can freely fish for poison.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Hydreigon carves a niche in National Dex courtesy of its powerful Choice Specs-boosted attacks and nearly unresisted STAB combo. Additionally, its useful typing allows it to pivot into common defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Gholdengo, giving it opportunities of entry. Fire Blast complements Dark Pulse and Draco Meteor very well, hitting Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Flash Cannon allows Hydreigon to hit Fairy-types that would otherwise pivot into it, such as Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant, as well as hitting Mega Tyranitar moderately hard. U-turn is an alternative over the latter two moves that provides a more risk-free option to exploit Hydreigon's checks, giving Pokemon like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny free entry. Tera Dark further boosts Hydreigon’s power, allowing its Dark Pulse to reliably 2HKO the likes of Toxapex and Heatran. Hydreigon fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that have reliable options to switch it in safely. Hydreigon pairs very well with pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T, as they can switch it in against opposing defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Rotom-W. Assault Vest Tornadus-T pairs particularly well with Hydreigon, as it notably checks Dragapult, as well as providing insurance against foes such as Iron Valiant. Pokemon that can exploit common switch-ins to Hydreigon such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit pair well with Hydreigon, meaning the likes of Great Tusk and Zamazenta are good partners. Similarly, Pokemon that can lure or weaken the aforementioned switchins, such as Gholdengo and Dragapult, pair well with Hydreigon.

sets.name: Fire Spin
sets.description: With its solid natural bulk and good defensive typing in conjunction with Levitate, Hydreigon serves as a trapper that checks and eliminates Pokemon like Skeledirge and Mega Charizard Y lacking Focus Blast. Fire Spin traps and accumulates chip on a myriad of defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, Gastrodon, and Clodsire. Earth Power, in combination with Fire Spin, increases the damage that the aforementioned Pokemon take while also threatening Heatran. Alternatively, Dark Pulse can be used as a solid STAB move to hit airborne Pokemon such as Gliscor. Taunt prevents passive walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon from healing while also preventing Hydreigon from being crippled by status from the aforementioned Pokemon as well. Tera Poison gives Hydreigon a Toxic immunity and a favorable defensive typing, allowing it to safely trap Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant. Offensive teammates like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, and Dragapult appreciate Hydreigon trapping and removing walls like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Gastrodon support Hydreigon, as they heavily chip and pressure switch-ins like Kingambit in combination with Hydreigon's Fire Spin. Hydreigon is easily forced out by Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant. As such, Pokemon that can handle the aforementioned threats such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex make great teammates for it.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona makes for a threatening late-game sweeper thanks to Quiver Dance, strong coverage moves, and a decent defensive profile. Fire Blast can be slotted over Flamethrower to hit much harder, notably OHKOing most variants of Gholdengo, but Flamethrower is usually better because of its consistency. Volcarona can utilize Giga Drain with Tera Grass to hit a plethora of Water-type Pokemon like Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Urshifu-R hard, in addition to Ground- and Rock-types such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Hidden Power Ground and Tera Ground help Volcarona bypass checks like Toxapex and Heatran after slight chip damage while also removing Volcarona’s glaring Rock weakness. Psychic with Tera Psychic allows Volcarona to break through Clodsire and Toxapex more reliably, but it is inferior to either of the previously mentioned Tera types due to its greater vulnerability to being revenge killed, and it leaves Volcarona completely stonewalled by Heatran. Flame Body can threaten to burn physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta, crippling them. Maximum Speed investment and a Timid Nature lets Volcarona outrun Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Urshifu-R after a boost. Modest can be run to hit walls like Clodsire and Toxapex harder, but it leaves Volcarona much more vulnerable to the aforementioned Choice Scarf users. Volcarona’s defensive utility is appreciated by allies such as Urshifu-R and Kingambit, as it can check dangerous Fighting-types like Iron Valiant and Zamazenta in a pinch. Bulky Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp can use it as setup fodder—with the latter additionally threatening Volcarona’s longevity with Toxic—so allies that can handle them such as Ferrothorn and Rotom-W are great partners to support Volcarona in its sweep. Heatran and Toxapex wall Volcarona if it doesn’t have Hidden Power Ground, so teammates like that can check them such as Garchomp and the aforementioned Rotom-W are much appreciated. Heatran also makes for a great ally, as it can eliminate or cripple Toxapex, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, which clears the way for Volcarona to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Bulky Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona distinguishes itself as a bulky setup sweeper by boasting reliable recovery, Quiver Dance, and being able to check Zamazenta and Iron Valiant with its unique typing. Bug Buzz can hit Mega Gyarados, Garchomp, and Mega Latias harder, but Giga Drain can be run to hit Water-types such as Urshifu-R, Gastrodon, and Rotom-W. Psychic can also be ran to threaten Clodsire and Toxapex. Will-O-Wisp makes Volcarona more utility-oriented, threatening physical attackers like Zamazenta and Dragonite with a burn more reliably, crippling them. However, the lack of coverage leaves Volcarona walled easily by most Fire-resistant Pokemon. The given Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outspeed Dragapult after a Quiver Dance, with the rest invested in HP and Defense so that it will always be 3HKOed by Zamazenta and defensive Great Tusk’s Earthquake. Volcarona struggles with status conditions, as they can hinder its ability to check threats like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant in the long term, thus status absorbers like Gliscor and Toxapex make good partners; the former provides Defog support, a Knock Off absorber, and a Heatran check, and the latter helps prepare Volcarona’s sweep with Knock Off and status inducement. Volcarona can be easily exploited by setup sweepers like Garchomp, Dragapult, Mega Tyranitar, and Dragonite, and so checks like Rotom-W, Kingambit, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Lele can help to alleviate these matchups.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Greninja is the fastest Choice Scarf user in the metagame, taking advantage of its blistering Speed tier and colorful Protean-boosted coverage to be a strong revenge killer and offensive pivot. Gunk Shot decimates Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. Ice Beam covers a plethora of Pokemon, including Tornadus-T, Dragapult, Kartana, and Landorus-T. Rock Slide deals with Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Aside from enabling Greninja to pivot, U-turn also provides coverage against Mega Tyranitar, Mega Gyarados, and opposing Greninja. The Special Attack EVs guarantee the OHKO against Kartana with Ice Beam. Terastallizing is mainly used to improve its offensive capabilities; for instance, Tera Poison gives Gunk Shot significant odds to OHKO specially defensive Tera Grass Heatran, Clefable, and Tera Fairy Garganacl after Stealth Rock, while Tera Ice boosts Ice Beam to OHKO Dragapult and physically defensive Tangrowth and Great Tusk. Wallbreakers like Garchomp, Zamazenta, Tapu Lele, and Mega Charizard Y appreciate Greninja's U-turn bringing them in safely on foes like Heatran, Garganacl, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, respectively. Garchomp also provides entry hazards to punish Greninja's forced switches, chipping down the likes of Garganacl and Heatran. In return, Greninja outpaces faster threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult that would otherwise overwhelm them. Greninja can form a VoltTurn core with Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Mega Scizor; the former two also provide Defog so Greninja can pivot more freely, especially if running Tera Ice.

sets.name: Unburden Sweeper
sets.description: Hawlucha is a terrifying setup sweeper with a stellar Speed tier alongside Unburden to instantly outspeed the entire metagame, including boosted foes like Iron Valiant, +2 Mega Gyarados, and weather sweepers such as Mega Swampert and—with the given Speed EVs—Excadrill. Its high-powered STAB moves—which can be boosted further by Swords Dance—hit almost the entire metagame neutrally; Acrobatics grants Hawlucha strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Tapu Lele, which is backed up by Close Combat to decimate Flying-resistant Pokemon like Kingambit, Garganacl, and Mega Tyranitar. Its item instantly activates Unburden under the corresponding Terrain and grants it setup opportunities from the Defense boost, especially in conjunction with Roost. Electric Seed helps against Kingambit, Zamazenta, and Great Tusk and prevents revenge killing attempts from Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Weavile's Ice Shard, while Psychic Seed helps against Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Choice-locked Dragapult. Taunt or Substitute deals with problematic walls, ignoring status like Toxapex's Toxic and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp; Taunt also prevents their recovery and phazing as well as Defense-boosting attempts such as from Skarmory or Tera Water Buzzwole, while Substitute blocks Landorus-T's Intimidate and punishes the use of weak attacks like its U-turn, Garganacl's Salt Cure, and Alomomola's Scald. The bulk investment allows Hawlucha to survive Clefable's Moonblast, which is unnecessary if running Psychic Seed. 176 Speed EVs can be used instead to revenge kill +1 Dragon Dance Dragapult. Tera Flying boosts Hawlucha's Acrobatics, potentially OHKOing Clefable at +2 and letting it set up against defensive Tornadus-T if necessary. The corresponding Alolan Guardian is a mandatory teammate to reliably activate Hawlucha's Unburden; Tapu Koko provides dual screens and brings Hawlucha in safely on Tangrowth and Ferrothorn with U-turn, while Tapu Lele pressures Toxapex and overwhelms Gholdengo. Offensive Pokemon on hyper offense teams such as Iron Valiant, Volcarona, Dragonite, and Mega Gyarados help maintain offensive pressure against the opposition; notably, they can force damage onto shared checks like Gholdengo, Skeledirge, Zapdos, and Toxapex, respectively, for Hawlucha to sweep more easily.

sets.name: The Pex
sets.description: Toxapex acts as a fantastic defensive pivot on bulkier playstyles courtesy of its excellent bulk and Regenerator. This allows it to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Dragapult and Zamazenta and pivot around powerful attackers such as Iron Valiant. Scald and Knock Off allow Toxapex to meaningfully threaten foes and make progress by either causing crippling status or removing the foe's item respectively, while Toxic takes advantage of Toxapex's excellent bulk and Regenerator, putting foes on a timer for its teammates. Haze removes boosts from the likes of Dragon Dance Dragapult and Espathra. Other options such as Toxic Spikes and Baneful Bunker can be explored over either Toxic or Haze, with the intent to cripple offensive teams or maximize Toxapex's ability to scout and pivot, respectively. However, removing Toxic leaves Toxapex worse off against common Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Rotom-W, while removing Haze makes it harder to handle setup sweepers. Although Toxapex rarely Terastallizes, Tera Dragon ensures Rotom-W's Volt Switch never outdamages Regenerator while also removing its Ground and Electric weaknesses against the likes of Great Tusk and Tapu Koko. The EV spread maximizes Toxapex's physical Bulk while allowing it to survive two Scorching Sands from Mega Charizard Y. Toxapex fits best on defensively oriented teams, which don't mind its passivity and can make up for any of its defensive shortcomings. Toxapex pairs well with Unaware Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Clodsire, which can handle setup sweepers that Toxapex falters to such as Kingambit and Gholdengo. In return, Toxapex sponges various weaker attacks using Regenerator from the likes of Gastrodon and Rotom-W. Toxapex dislikes losing its item, as it can easily be pushed into KO range against wallbreakers such as Zamazenta and Dragapult alongside entry hazards. As such, Pokemon that can generally withstand Knock Off well, such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor, pair excellently with it. Tornadus-T in particular makes for a great partner, as it can use Regenerator alongside Toxapex, pivoting between each other to handle Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Toxapex appreciates extra insurance against strong special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. As such, Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Heatran pair well, especially since Toxapex can switch into the Shadow Balls and Focus Blasts aimed that them respectively.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Cinderace serves as a dangerous wallbreaker, as it easily exploits would-be checks thanks to its ability, Libero. Double-Edge becomes a STAB move after using Swords Dance, allowing Cinderace to not only wound Pokemon like Toxapex and Slowbro but also OHKO them with Normalium Z. High Jump Kick KOes Heatran and Mega Tyranitar, while Sucker Punch threatens faster Pokemon like Dragapult and Tornadus-T. Pokemon that can set entry hazards such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Ting-Lu help Cinderace break through its checks like Great Tusk and Tera Dragon Skarmory. Cinderace is vulnerable to faster Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Tapu Koko, so Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Landorus-T are good teammates. Cinderace also benefits from dual screens from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl, allowing it to safely set up and start wreaking havoc on the opponent. Pokemon that can wear down Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Tera Dragon Skarmory such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gyarados, and Dragapult form great offensive cores with Cinderace, which, in return, threatens Pokemon like Toxapex, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. Entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Great Tusk support Cinderace's Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Cinderace utilizes its solid coverage alongside Libero and its high Attack and Speed to serve as a strong offensive pivot. High Jump Kick OHKOes foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran while hitting others like Garganacl and Ting-Lu, though Cinderace must be mindful of Protect from the former and Tera Ghost from the latter causing it to take heavy recoil. U-turn lets Cinderace generate momentum, pivoting on switch-ins such as Toxapex and Slowbro to bring in teammates like Tapu Koko and Gholdengo that can handle them. Sucker Punch lets Cinderace threaten Dragapult, which would otherwise revenge kill it. Tera Fire boosts Pyro Ball's power, allowing Cinderace to 2HKO foes such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Tera Fairy Garganacl after Stealth Rock. Cinderace must careful when using Tera, however, as Libero will no longer activate, leaving it more vulnerable to foes such as Rotom-W. Cinderace fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its pivoting ability. Tapu Koko forms a potent pivoting core with Cinderace, taking advantage of foes such as Toxapex and Rotom-W while granting Cinderace free entry against foes such as Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. They also overwhelm foes such as Ladorus-T, Gastrodon, and Great Tusk together. Cinderace also appreciates teammates such as Ferrothorn and Gastrodon providing entry hazard support to weaken foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk while also checking foes such as Rotom-W and Urshifu-R. Dragapult appreciates Cinderace handling foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit; in return, it threatens foes such as Skeledirge, which Cinderace struggles against. Future Sight support from teammates such as Slowbro and Tapu Lele helps pressure foes such as Toxapex for Cinderace; in return, Cinderace handles foes that threaten them such as Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Corviknight is a poor Defogger in the metagame, but its defensive profile still allows it to check Mega Lopunny, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Kartana. It also individually beats hazard setters like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Clodsire. Brave Bird is the preferred option that pressures Dragapult, Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, and Iron Valiant, while Body Press pressures Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Weavile. Iron Defense or Bulk Up can be used over Defog to turn Corviknight into a bulky win condition and to improve its ability to check threats like Kingambit, Urshifu-R, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Body Press should be used with Iron Defense, while Brave Bird can instead be used with Bulk Up. U-turn allows Corviknight to maintain momentum against the threats that it checks while also bringing in frailer teammates. The given HP and Defense EVs allow Corviknight to live a +2 Continental Crush from Landorus-T, while the rest of the EVs being in Special Defense helps out against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Rocky Helmet allows Corviknight to chip threats like Mega Lopunny and Weavile. Tera Dragon removes Corviknight's Electric and Fire weaknesses and potentially allows it to turn the tables on Heatran and Rotom-W. Tera Ground can instead be used to halt Volt Switch attempts and surprise Tapu Koko, but the resistances it grants are not as consistently valuable as Dragon. Corviknight's biggest problem by far is Gholdengo, which blocks Corviknight's Defog attempts and sets up on it. Options that deal with it, such as Kingambit, Weavile, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire are therefore mandatory partners. U-turn can bring in the former two to Pursuit trap Gholdengo, while the latter two can stave it off defensively. Kingambit is especially potent with Corviknight, as it appreciates Corviknight's Rocky Helmet applying chip damage onto its checks like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. U-turn can also bring in other threats safely, such as Dragapult, Walking Wake, and Heatran. Corviknight's defensive profile gets taken advantage of by threats like Heatran, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona, so options such as your own Heatran, Garchomp, and Toxapex can help out in this regard.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Corviknight is a formidable wincon that takes advantage of its typing and impressive bulk to garner boosts. It also provides a sturdy defensive backbone, consistently checking threats such as Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragonite. However, as Corviknight lacks immediate offensive presence and coverage, it suffers from being forced out by the likes of Zapdos and Heatran and being setup fodder from the likes of Kingambit and Gholdengo. Pressure, in conjunction with Substitute, allows Corviknight to PP stall checks like Heatran and Skarmory safely while bypassing status moves like Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp and Clefable's Thunder Wave. Tera Water improves the matchup against Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R, giving crucial resistances to safely let Corviknight boost up. Alternatively, Tera Dragon lets it take on Electric-types like Zapdos and Rotom-W while also helping against Heatran and Urshifu-R. However, Pokemon like Mega Diancie, Weavile, and Dragapult can now almost always force it out, though they do have to watch out for repeated Brave Bird hits. The given EV spread maximizes special bulk while still being able to survive a +2 Continental Crush from Garchomp followed by Stone Edge after Roost; it also lets Corviknight outspeed Skarmory and become only 3HKOed by Great Tusk's Close Combat. However, note that Corviknight will be taking a super effective Body Press from Skarmory after using Roost. Corviknight fits best on bulkier teams, which appreciate its ability to PP stall threats like Heatran and Toxapex while being a solid wincon. Pokemon like Toxapex and Clefable thus work well with it. Toxapex appreciates Corviknight reliably checking Tapu Lele and Landorus-T for it. In return, Toxapex helps check Weavile, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, which Corviknight struggles to do. Calm Mind Clefable loves Corviknight draining PP from opposing Toxapex’s Haze; in return, it softens up Heatran. Ground-types like Gliscor and Great Tusk make excellent partners, as they absorb Electric attacks from the likes of Tapu Koko and remove entry hazards from the field. In exchange, Corviknight helps take Kyurem and Iron Valiant’s attacks. Due to Corviknight being walled by Electric- and Steel-types, such as Zapdos and Gholdengo, partners that can threaten them such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran work well with it.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Thanks to its high offensive stats alongside Swift Swim, Choice Band Barraskewda is a premier wallbreaker, offensive pivot, late-game cleaner, and revenge killer on rain teams. Its blistering Speed tier allows it to nearly outpace the entire metagame under rain, including boosted foes like Dragon Dance Dragapult and Mega Swampert. Liquidation's Defense drop lets it potentially 2HKO Pokemon such as Dragapult and Pelipper, while Waterfall's flinches gives Barraskewda slightly better odds to muscle past the likes of Slowbro and Toxapex. Flip Turn keeps up momentum by providing free entry for its teammates while chipping down switch-ins like Dondozo and Tangrowth. Close Combat hits Water-resistant foes such as Ferrothorn, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados, and it provides strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tera Water Great Tusk, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Gastrodon. Aqua Jet prevents Barraskewda from being revenge killed by priority attacks like Kingambit and Mega Mawile's Sucker Punch and—if rain is not active—lets it pick off faster threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill and boosted Volcarona and Iron Valiant. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs pressures Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Water Absorb Clodsire better. Tera Water skyrockets Barraskewda's rain-boosted STAB moves further, potentially 2HKOing even Water-resistant Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Pelipper is a necessary teammate that spearheads rain teams by reliably summoning rain with Drizzle. Mega Swampert is a fantastic offensive partner that can overwhelm shared checks like Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Slowbro and appreciates Barraskewda's Flip Turn to bring it in safely on foes such as Toxapex, Dragapult, and Dragonite. Tornadus-T and Ferrothorn are rain team staples that support Barraskewda with Knock Off, crippling walls such as Rotom-W and opposing Ferrothorn; Ferrothorn in particular helps threaten Gastrodon with Power Whip and sets entry hazards to soften up foes. The aforementioned Pelipper and Tornadus-T also provide Defog support for Barraskewda to pivot throughout the game unperturbed, bring it in safely via U-turn, and threatens problematic Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran.
